​Longevity drugs for dogs help humans too - The Times of India
summary:
Longevity Drugs for Dogs Help Humans Too

Publication Date: Not provided | Source: Not specified

Recent studies suggest that longevity drugs developed for canines may also have significant benefits for human health. This breakthrough highlights the interconnectedness of veterinary and human medical research.

  • Research indicates that compounds used in dog longevity treatments may enhance human healthspan.
  • The findings bring new perspectives on aging and disease prevention in humans.
  • Veterinary advancements often contribute to significant strides in human medicine.
"The implications of this research could change the way we approach aging in both dogs and humans alike."

This intersection of veterinary and human health science continues to offer exciting possibilities for combating aging and improving life quality across species.
newTitle: Longevity Drugs for Dogs Help Humans Too

title: Emergence of coinfection with visceral Leishmania infantum in COVID-19 patients: a case‒control field study in an endemic area of visceral leishmaniasis in Iran - BMC Infectious Diseases
summary:
Emergence of Coinfection with Visceral Leishmania infantum in COVID-19 Patients: A Case-Control Field Study in an Endemic Area of Visceral Leishmaniasis in Iran

Published: 30 December 2024 | Source: BMC Infectious Diseases

This study examines the prevalence of Leishmania infantum coinfection in COVID-19 patients in a site endemic to visceral leishmaniasis in Iran.

  • 250 blood samples from hospitalized COVID-19 patients and 231 from a control group were analyzed.
  • 18.4% of COVID-19 patients tested positive for L. infantum, compared to 7.8% in the control group.
  • COVID-19 patients had a 2.66 times greater chance of having L. infantum infection.
  • No significant association was found between L. infantum infection and various patient demographics or treatment outcomes.
"The overall seroprevalence of L. infantum infection among patients with COVID-19 was 2.66 times greater than that in the control group."

This study emphasizes the potential risk factor of L. infantum infection in COVID-19 patients, particularly in endemic areas.
newTitle: Emergence of Coinfection with Visceral Leishmania infantum in COVID-19 Patients in Iran

Weight-Loss Drugs, Wily Viruses, Abortion Pill Under Attack: The Top Health Stories of 2024 - HealthDay
summary:
Weight-Loss Drugs, Wily Viruses, Abortion Pill Under Attack: The Top Health Stories of 2024

Date: December 30, 2024 | Source: HealthDay News

This year in health news presented significant advancements alongside formidable challenges, including the impact of weight-loss drugs, emerging viral threats, and contentious debates over abortion pill access.

  • GLP-1 weight-loss drugs, like Ozempic, led to a slight decline in obesity rates in the U.S.
  • Bird flu (H5N1) outbreaks affected over 900 dairy herds, raising public health concerns.
  • Severe mpox variants emerged, prompting a WHO declaration of a public health emergency.
  • Access to abortion pills has been hotly contested in conservative states since the overturning of Roe v. Wade.
  • The incoming Trump administration is expected to challenge longstanding public health policies.
“The last year suggests [GLP-1 drugs] could change the health landscape as much as cholesterol-lowering medications did when they were first introduced.”

As 2025 approaches, the landscape of public health remains uncertain, with ongoing debates likely to shape future policy and people's health.
newTitle: Top Health Stories of 2024: Breakthroughs and Challenges

Most of 2024’s dengue cases in Goa were detected in non-monsoon period - The Times of India
summary:
Dengue Cases in Goa Rise During Non-Monsoon Season in 2024

Publication Date: October 2023 | Source: Times of India

Goa has seen a significant number of dengue cases in the year 2024, predominantly occurring outside the typical monsoon season, raising concerns among health officials.

  • The majority of dengue cases were reported from January to May.
  • Health officials are investigating the unusual seasonal trend.
  • Local health services are preparing for potential outbreaks as winter approaches.
“We are monitoring the situation closely to avoid larger outbreaks.” - State health official

This shift in dengue patterns could indicate changing climate conditions and necessitates ongoing public health vigilance.
newTitle: Dengue Cases in Goa Rise During Non-Monsoon Season in 2024

title: Five years on, WHO urges China to share Covid origins data - Firstpost
summary:
WHO Calls on China for Covid Origins Data After Five Years

Publication Date: Monday

Source: Reuters

Five years after the beginning of the Covid-19 pandemic, the World Health Organization (WHO) is urging China to share crucial data related to the origins of the virus.

  • The WHO emphasizes the need for transparency and cooperation to prevent future pandemics.
  • Covid-19 has had devastating effects globally, resulting in millions of deaths and economic turmoil.
  • The WHO recalled how it first learned of the viral pneumonia cases in Wuhan, which marked the onset of the pandemic.
  • WHO Director General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus indicates that while the world has improved its pandemic preparedness, vulnerabilities still persist.
  • Negotiations for a global accord on pandemic prevention are ongoing, with challenges related to equity between wealthy and poorer nations.
“Without transparency, sharing, and cooperation among countries, the world cannot adequately prevent and prepare for future epidemics and pandemics.” - WHO Statement

The WHO's call for cooperation and data sharing highlights the ongoing importance of understanding Covid-19's origins to prepare for future health crises.
newTitle: WHO Calls on China for Covid Origins Data After Five Years
